thread.title: 11 Christ-Honoring NFL Players To Watch This Football Season

author: @smartin_write
title: 11 Christ-Honoring NFL Players To Watch This Football Season
text:
Every fall, the kickoff of another church-programming year coincides with the new NFL season. Likewise, many pro football players profess deep Christian faith while using their God-given athletic talents.
Yes, football games might occasionally prevent some worshipers from coming to church on Sundays. But sports can also serve as a segue to conversations about glorifying Jesus in our careers and conversations.
To help spark discussions about Christian living, ChurchLeaders often profiles athletes who honor God. For the 2024 NFL kickoff, here’s a fresh lineup of faith-filled NFL players:
11 NFL Players Who Give God Glory 1. Grant Stuard (Indianapolis Colts) For years, Grant Stuard lied about his home life, trying to hide the instability he and his younger siblings faced. Their mother was a sex worker and a drug addict, and their father had a lengthy arrest and prison record.
By age 20, Stuard decided he’d had enough. With both his football and academic performance slipping, the University of Houston student drove to a cliff, intending to jump off. What made him reconsider? He heard the far-off sound of laughter from a father-son fishing duo below.
At a church service months later, Stuard heard a word of prophecy that touched his heart. “For me, that was God showing me he existed,” said the athlete, now 25. “[God] was telling me he cared about me, like genuinely cared about me, something that was missing my whole life.”
After that, Stuard got his life back on track—and helped his family do the same. He insisted that his mother stick with rehab and give him custody of his younger sister.
In the 2021 NFL Draft, Stuard was the final pick, known as Mr. Irrelevant. But that achievement was incredibly relevant and meaningful for Stuard, based on everything he’d already overcome.
The Indianapolis Colts special teams player, who’s heading into his fourth NFL season, is also a husband, new father, rapper, and philanthropist. His foundation raises money to fight poverty, hunger, and sex trafficking in his hometown of Houston.
Stuard is upfront about how God transformed his life. “I would like to thank Jesus Christ, the Lord of my life, for completely changing me and making me into the person I am today,” he posted in 2020. “I want to encourage anyone who does not have a relationship with Jesus to seek Him. You will not be disappointed.”
Last December on the Sports Spectrum podcast , Stuard shared, “I spent a good amount of time walking and living my life without Jesus and without a purpose. So [when] I finally made a connection with him and surrendered my life over to him, life became life.”
2. Brandin Cooks (Dallas Cowboys) Before landing in Dallas, veteran Brandin Cooks played with four other teams. But the 30-year-old wide receiver out of Oregon State believes frequent trades offer some advantages.
They’re “an opportunity to be able to go around and make my mark on different cities, different people, different locker rooms, still at the same time producing at a high level,” said Cooks. “I look at it as a great thing, in a sense. I’d rather that than get cut five, six times.”
When Cooks played for the Rams, punter Johnny Hekker called him “a spiritual spark” whose faith was “no secret to anybody.”
In May, Cooks partnered with He Gets Us to hold a football camp for 700 kids in his hometown of Stockton, California. The wide receiver said the He Gets Us movement shares his passion for loving our neighbors.
“Our neighbor is someone that may not look like us, talk like us, dress like us,” Cooks told Fox Sports Digital . “We were called to love, and God will take care of everything else. We’ve just gotta continue to be that example on how to love, even in the most uncomfortable moments.”
When Cooks says faith in Christ is his foundation, that’s not just lip service: “I truly mean it when I say it. Everything I have, everything I’ve been blessed with, even from the good to the not so good. [Jesus has] always been my foundation growing up, and [I] just continue to be able to be a light in this world today.”
3. Bo Nix (Denver Broncos) After a close quarterback competition during training camp, the Denver Broncos named rookie Bo Nix as their starter. Then on Sept. 4, they named him the first rookie team captain since 1967.
All summer, Nix’s new teammates and coaches described him as “mature.” Part of that could be his age, 24. Because of pandemic -related eligibility rules, Nix started 61 college games, the most ever for an NCAA quarterback. Plus, Nix is already married.
But the maturity also might stem from being grounded in faith . “God has ordered my steps,” Nix said in 2021, while transferring from Auburn to Oregon . “And [God] has a plan for me like he does for everyone else.”
Back in high school, Nix was already talking publicly about his beliefs. On the Sports Spectrum podcast in 2018, the athlete said he wanted to help people know “it’s not weird or different to…do what’s right and be a Christ-follower.”
After being drafted No. 12 overall in April, Nix referenced Isaiah 55:9 , saying he believes God’s plans are higher than our ways. He’s a “perfect example” of that, the QB added: “You can look at my story and know that [God] has an individual plan for each one of our lives. He sets it out in front of us, and all we have to do is follow.”
4. DeAndre Hopkins (Tennessee Titans) For Tennessee Titans wide receiver DeAndre Hopkins , faith and family define him as much as football does. The South Carolina native, who was baptized in 2012 while playing at Clemson, calls his relationship with God a “major part of my life.”
That faith has helped Hopkins, 32, persevere amid tragedy. When he was just 5 months old, his father was killed in a car accident. Then in 2002, his mother, Sabrina Greenlee , was blinded by an acid attack.
After every touchdown Hopkins scores, he gives his mom the ball. He also wrote the foreword to her new memoir, “ Grant Me Vision: A Journey of Family, Faith, and Forgiveness .” In the book, Greenlee describes how hardships have built character.
Congratulating his mom on her book launch, Hopkins posted, “From selling drugs just to feed four kids , to overcoming depression from being blind. This is more than a book, it’s Us.”
Despite the family’s struggles, “my mom made sure I knew about God,” Hopkins said. “She raised us in tough times, held down two jobs, and I watched her faith grow stronger and stronger.”
5. Adoreé Jackson (New York Giants) Another NFL player influenced by his mother’s strong Christian faith is Adoreé Jackson . The 28-year-old New York Giants cornerback said the selflessness of his mom, Vianca Jackson , qualifies her as a true hero. While her son was attending the University of Southern California, she kept her breast cancer diagnosis from him so it wouldn’t be a burden or distraction.
“I didn’t want his grades to drop; I didn’t want him to get hurt in any sport,” Vianca said in 2017, after beating cancer. “I wanted [Adoreé] to keep his mind clear and keep his focus on Jesus. I knew I was going to be okay.”
Jackson said of his mom , “She taught me to cherish what I have. Seeing her faith in God and her belief showed me that if I keep those things as well, things will work out for me.” Jackson also thanked God for “never letting my faith waver, never letting me stray.” Quoting Proverbs 22:6 , he said his parents raised him up in the way he should go.
That’s crucial in a sport played mostly on Sundays. “You don’t get to go to as much church as back in the day when you were kids,” the athlete said. “But I understand the teachings that [my parents] told me, that the Bible taught me, or school has taught me, or church.”
Before being selected in the first round of the 2017 draft, Jackson posted, “I have faith that God is living out a divine plan through me. Have faith in God. – Mark 11:22 .”
6. Ben Stille (Arizona Cardinals) At 26, defensive lineman Ben Stille has already played for three NFL teams. The journeyman out of Nebraska has experienced the pressures—and frequent moves—of trying to succeed as a pro.
Now with Arizona, Stille has shifted back and forth from the Cardinals’ active roster to the practice squad. But no matter where he lands, he’s determined to make the most of his gifts, knowing they come from God.
That attitude “stems from my faith in Jesus Christ,” Stille said on the “ Pro Mindset ” podcast. “In my mind, just playing for him and really his judgment is the only one that matters to me.”
It’s been “a huge step…to figure out that my faith isn’t something that’s just lived out in church. It’s lived out in my day-to-day life,” the athlete added. “And ultimately, God has called me to be a professional football player. That’s where I spend most of my time, and that’s where, in this stage of my life, I’m called to live out my faith.”
Stille is also now living out his faith as a new dad. This summer, he and his wife welcomed their first child.
At Nebraska, where Stille excelled in the classroom as well as on the field, he was involved with the Fellowship of Christian Athletes . In a 2019 Instagram post, he wrote, “Had an awesome time leading a group of middle schoolers and sharing my testimony at FCA leadership camp this week! All the Glory be to God! # Ephesians 2:8-10 .”
7. Will Anderson Jr. (Houston Texans) At the NFL Honors in February 2024, Will Anderson Jr. was one of several award winners who publicly praised God. The Houston Texans defensive end, named Defensive Rookie of the Year, said, “Without [God], none of this is possible. He deserves all the honor and praise.”
According to Anderson , serving God is much more important than any football accolade. “My focus is just less on what everybody has to say and more on God,” he said this summer at training camp. “I think my biggest thing is knowing that, like I always tell y’all, my approval comes from him. Ultimately, everything that I achieve in this lifetime, I’m putting him first for it, because he’s the reason why I’m here.”
The 23-year-old added, “I just want to be a servant, be a leader, and be a blessing to my teammates and help them out in any type of way. So that’s my whole thing coming into this year. It’s like, ‘God, however you want to use me, I just want to be a blessing to this team.’”
Anderson also was vocal about his faith while playing at Alabama. Now he’s teammates with outspoken Christian C.J. Stroud , last season’s Offensive Rookie of the Year.
Anderson credited Houston’s staff for offering spiritual support during his rookie year. Last season, they helped him “be closer to God and understanding his Word and knowing how special he is and how much grace and mercy that he has over our lives.” The defensive end expressed awe at how God works, providing faith mentors and placing him in situations to show that “I always got my hand on you.”
8. Bijan Robinson (Atlanta Falcons) For 22-year-old first-round draft pick Bijan Robinson , faith and football have been intertwined from a young age. As a child, he carried around a football like a security blanket—and once even snuck it into church. He also filled sticky notes with prayers such as “God, take me to the NFL” and “At the end of the day, make me special.”
After the Atlanta Falcons drafted him eighth overall in 2023, Robinson praised the Lord, saying, “I really can’t wait to see what God has in store for me.” Telling fans he has a big heart, the running back promised to “bring my faith, my positivity, my happiness and smile” to them all.
Although Robinson never knew his biological father, he was surrounded by family growing up. His grandmother was his Sunday school teacher, and his grandfather—a former college football official—guided his athletic pursuits. His aunt is now his manager.
While playing college ball at Texas, Robinson described how that school’s program nurtured his faith. “None of us would be here if God wasn’t a part of our life. He blessed us to do something,” he said. “So when he’s the center and the focal piece of a team, then that’s when you start to see where you want to go and how you want to do it.”
9. Daniel Carlson (Las Vegas Raiders) Daniel Carlson is an All-Pro, record-setting placekicker for the Las Vegas Raiders . During four years at Auburn, he never missed an extra point. Most importantly, after growing up in a Christian home, the athlete made his faith his own during college.
Carlson , 29, shares Proverbs 3:5-6 on his social media bios: “Trust in the Lord with all your heart and lean not on your own understanding; in all your ways submit to him, and he will make your paths straight.”
The dad of three young children said fatherhood has helped him understand the unconditional love that God the Father has for us. On the Sports Spectrum podcast in June, Carlson expressed the relief of knowing that God will love us no matter how much we screw up. That sacrificial love and the gift of grace are “everything,” said the kicker, ahead of his seventh year as a pro.
Carlson said he gains confidence from God’s continued faithfulness and from reading the Bible before games. The veteran player, who now leads some team Bible studies, said it’s exciting when teammates ask questions about Christianity and take steps of faith.
10. Jalen Ramsey (Miami Dolphins) “Child of God through my faith in Christ”—that’s how Miami Dolphins cornerback Jalen Ramsey describes himself on social media. For some people, that might appear to clash with his reputation as a trash-talker.
But Ramsey, who won a Super Bowl with the Los Angeles Rams, said he’s never cared what other people think about him. “Most of the time, their perception is wrong,” he said. “Also, I just don’t play for humans. I play for all glory to God.” The 29-year-old pushes back against people who call him cocky, saying, “Thinking less of myself” would be “doing a discredit to God,” who has “ blessed me with so much.”
Ramsey, whose grandmother is a retired pastor , is determined to raise his daughters in the faith. “They know that without Jesus Christ we’re nothing, but with Jesus Christ we’re everything,” he told CBS Sports . “They pray every single night with me. Things like that, people don’t know. But I don’t really broadcast or care to broadcast, because that’s not really why I do it. That’s not who I do it for.”
Ramsey is also serious about giving back , saying, “You’ve gotta put action with your beliefs.”
When asked if he’d consider going into ministry once he hangs up his cleats, Ramsey shakes his head no. “In essence, though, I think anybody can encourage others,” he noted. “Anybody can be a pastor , right? I’ve always wanted to do it in a little bit of a different way.”
The cornerback said he might coach high school players someday, “encouraging the kids with not only my knowledge about the game of football but about life and about Jesus Christ.”
11. Reid Ferguson (Buffalo Bills) Long snapper Reid Ferguson is heading into his eighth NFL season—all with the Buffalo Bills. The 30-year-old outspoken Christian has expressed gratitude for Bills chaplain Len Vanden Bos and the team’s strong core of believers. Regular chapel services, Bible studies , and couples nights provide a “breath of fresh air” spiritually, said Ferguson. Plus, they’re a “great way to get the Word in front of more guys.”
Speaking to Sports Spectrum in 2022, Ferguson recapped his Southern Baptist upbringing in Georgia, including his involvement with Awana and youth group . At LSU, the athlete’s church attendance slid at first, before he rededicated himself to regular worship and reconnected with the Fellowship of Christian Athletes.
During a 2020 Facebook Live interview with Ferguson, New York Pastor Pat Jones noted that a long snapper receives little glory but is vital to the team. Similarly, all people play vital roles in the church, even if they’re not always publicly recognized.
In that interview, Ferguson shared tips for staying strong both physically and spiritually. “It has to be a daily thing” in both areas, he said. That’s why the athlete values opportunities to stay connected to God and to his Christ-following teammates. “Find a group of people who have your back,” Ferguson advised listeners.
As part of his efforts to give back to the Buffalo community, Ferguson supports military personnel and veterans. For two years in a row, he was named the Bills’ Salute to Service award nominee.
